trans-unit.source: Changing Computer State
trans-unit.target: Changing Computer State

trans-unit.source: powershell,cmdlet
trans-unit.target: powershell,cmdlet

trans-unit.source: Changing Computer State
trans-unit.target: Changing Computer State

trans-unit.source: To reset a computer in Windows PowerShell, use either a standard command-line tool or a WMI class.
trans-unit.target: To reset a computer in Windows PowerShell, use either a standard command-line tool or a WMI class.

trans-unit.source: Although you are using Windows PowerShell only to run the tool, learning how to change a computer's power state in Windows PowerShell illustrates some of the important details about working with external tools in Windows PowerShell.
trans-unit.target: Although you are using Windows PowerShell only to run the tool, learning how to change a computer's power state in Windows PowerShell illustrates some of the important details about working with external tools in Windows PowerShell.

trans-unit.source: Locking a Computer
trans-unit.target: Locking a Computer

trans-unit.source: The only way to lock a computer directly with the standard available tools is to call the **LockWorkstation()** function in **user32.dll**:
trans-unit.target: The only way to lock a computer directly with the standard available tools is to call the **LockWorkstation()** function in **user32.dll**:

trans-unit.source: This command immediately locks the workstation.
trans-unit.target: This command immediately locks the workstation.

trans-unit.source: It uses *rundll32.exe*, which runs Windows DLLs (and saves their libraries for repeated use) to run user32.dll, a library of Windows management functions.
trans-unit.target: It uses *rundll32.exe*, which runs Windows DLLs (and saves their libraries for repeated use) to run user32.dll, a library of Windows management functions.

trans-unit.source: When you lock a workstation while Fast User Switching is enabled, such as on Windows XP, the computer displays the user logon screen rather than starting the current user's screensaver.
trans-unit.target: When you lock a workstation while Fast User Switching is enabled, such as on Windows XP, the computer displays the user logon screen rather than starting the current user's screensaver.

trans-unit.source: To shut down particular sessions on a Terminal Server, use the **tsshutdn.exe** command-line tool.
trans-unit.target: To shut down particular sessions on a Terminal Server, use the **tsshutdn.exe** command-line tool.

trans-unit.source: Logging Off the Current Session
trans-unit.target: Logging Off the Current Session

trans-unit.source: You can use several different techniques to log off of a session on the local system.
trans-unit.target: You can use several different techniques to log off of a session on the local system.

trans-unit.source: The simplest way is to use the Remote Desktop/Terminal Services command-line tool, **logoff.exe** (For details, at the Windows PowerShell prompt, type **logoff /?**).
trans-unit.target: The simplest way is to use the Remote Desktop/Terminal Services command-line tool, **logoff.exe** (For details, at the Windows PowerShell prompt, type **logoff /?**).

trans-unit.source: To log off the current active session, type **logoff** with no arguments.
trans-unit.target: To log off the current active session, type **logoff** with no arguments.

trans-unit.source: You can also use the **shutdown.exe** tool with its logoff option:
trans-unit.target: You can also use the **shutdown.exe** tool with its logoff option:

trans-unit.source: A third option is to use WMI.
trans-unit.target: A third option is to use WMI.

trans-unit.source: The Win32_OperatingSystem class has a Win32Shutdown method.
trans-unit.target: The Win32_OperatingSystem class has a Win32Shutdown method.

trans-unit.source: Invoking the method with the 0 flag initiates logoff:
trans-unit.target: Invoking the method with the 0 flag initiates logoff:

trans-unit.source: For more information, and to find other features of the Win32Shutdown method, see "Win32Shutdown Method of the Win32_OperatingSystem Class" in MSDN.
trans-unit.target: For more information, and to find other features of the Win32Shutdown method, see "Win32Shutdown Method of the Win32_OperatingSystem Class" in MSDN.

trans-unit.source: Shutting Down or Restarting a Computer
trans-unit.target: Shutting Down or Restarting a Computer

trans-unit.source: Shutting down and restarting computers are generally the same types of task.
trans-unit.target: Shutting down and restarting computers are generally the same types of task.

trans-unit.source: Tools that shut down a computer will generally restart it as well—and vice versa.
trans-unit.target: Tools that shut down a computer will generally restart it as well—and vice versa.

trans-unit.source: There are two straightforward options for restarting a computer from Windows PowerShell.
trans-unit.target: There are two straightforward options for restarting a computer from Windows PowerShell.

trans-unit.source: Use either Tsshutdn.exe or Shutdown.exe with appropriate arguments.
trans-unit.target: Use either Tsshutdn.exe or Shutdown.exe with appropriate arguments.

trans-unit.source: You can get detailed usage information from **tsshutdn.exe /?**
trans-unit.target: You can get detailed usage information from **tsshutdn.exe /?**

trans-unit.source: or **shutdown.exe /?**.
trans-unit.target: or **shutdown.exe /?**.

trans-unit.source: You can also perform shutdown and restart operations by using **Win32_OperatingSystem** directly from Windows PowerShell as well.
trans-unit.target: You can also perform shutdown and restart operations by using **Win32_OperatingSystem** directly from Windows PowerShell as well.

trans-unit.source: To shut down the computer, use the Win32Shutdown method with the **1** flag.
trans-unit.target: To shut down the computer, use the Win32Shutdown method with the **1** flag.

trans-unit.source: To restart the operating system, use the Win32Shutdown method with the **2** flag.
trans-unit.target: To restart the operating system, use the Win32Shutdown method with the **2** flag.
